'''Colden Rainey Swindell''' (born June 30, 1983) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. He has written singles for [[Craig Campbell (singer)|Craig Campbell]], [[Thomas Rhett]], [[Scotty McCreery]], and [[Luke Bryan]], and has released four albums for [[Warner Bros. Records]] Nashville. He has released thirteen singles, eight of which have reached number one on the [[Hot Country Songs]] and/or [[Country Airplay]] charts. Three more singles have reached the Top 10.

==Early life==
Swindell was born on June 30, 1983, to William Keith Swindell and Betty Carol Rainey. His father died on September 2, 2013, at 65,<ref name=dad>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/savannah/obituary.aspx?pid=166791689|title=William Swindell Obituary|author=Swindell family|date=September 4, 2013|work=[[Savannah Morning News]]|access-date=February 15, 2014}}</ref> while his mother died in September 2021.<ref name=mom>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindells-mom-died/|title=Cole Swindell's Mom Has Died|last=Dukes|first=Billy|date=September 13, 2021|access-date=July 25, 2023|work=Taste of Country}}</ref> He grew up in [[Dawson, Georgia]], and has two brothers and a stepbrother.<ref name=dad />

Swindell attended [[Terrell Academy]] in [[Dawson, Georgia]].<ref name="walb150506">{{cite news|title=Swindell talks wild year, Terrell Academy days|url=http://www.walb.com/story/28988229/swindell-talks-wild-year-terrell-academy-days|access-date=14 January 2018|publisher=WALB|date=May 6, 2015}}</ref>  Swindell attended [[Georgia Southern University]], where he majored in marketing.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/06/12/cole-swindell-savors-defining-days/71095880/ |title=Cole Swindell savors his 'defining days' |author= Cindy Watts|date= June 14, 2015 |work=The Tennessean}}</ref> He met [[Luke Bryan]], who attended the same university some years earlier and was also a fellow [[Sigma Chi]] member,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2014/02/16/cole-swindell-on-the-verge-chillin-it/5368883/ |title= On the Verge: Cole Swindell no longer cooling his heels|author=Brian Mansfield |work= USA TODAY |date= February 16, 2014}}</ref> at the fraternity house when Bryan came back to [[Statesboro, Georgia|Statesboro]] to do a show. They kept in touch, and after Swindell left college in 2007 and moved to Nashville, he sold merchandise for Bryan for three years, and wrote songs on the road.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://radio.com/2014/02/13/new-music-to-know-how-cole-swindell/ |title=New Music to Know: How Cole Swindell Went From Luke Bryan's Merch Guy to Opening Act |date=February 13, 2014 |author=Annie Reuter |work=Radio.com }}</ref>

==Music career==
===Songwriting===
In 2010, Swindell signed a publishing deal with [[Sony/ATV Music Publishing]].

Swindell wrote [[Craig Campbell (singer)|Craig Campbell]]'s "[[Outta My Head (Craig Campbell song)|Outta My Head]]",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/music/craig-campbells-outta-my-head-lyric-video|title=Craig Campbell's "Outta My Head" Lyric Video|publisher=Country Weekly}}</ref> [[Luke Bryan]]'s "Just a Sip", "Beer in the Headlights", "[[Roller Coaster (Luke Bryan song)|Roller Coaster]]", "Out Like That", "I'm Hungover", "In Love with the Girl", Florida Georgia Line’s "[[This Is How We Roll]]" with Bryan, who was featured on the song. [[Chris Young (singer)|Chris Young]] also had a song on his ''[[A.M. (Chris Young album)|A.M.]]'' album co-written by Swindell, "Nothin' but the Cooler Left

===2013–2015: ''Cole Swindell''===
In 2013, Swindell's independently released debut single "[[Chillin' It]]", buoyed by heavy airplay on [[SiriusXM]] satellite radio channel "The Highway", became a hit<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/cole-swindell-mn0002795282/biography|title=Cole Swindell biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=14 February 2014}}</ref> and Swindell signed a record deal with [[Warner Music Group|Warner Music Nashville]]. The demo of "Chillin' It" was sent to radio before it had been [[audio mastering|mastered]].<ref name="tenn">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2014/02/12/father-and-son-producers-jeff-stevens-jody-stevens-celebrate-no-1-and-no-2-hits/|title=Father and son producers Jeff Stevens, Jody Stevens celebrate No. 1 and No. 2 hits|last=Watts|first=Cindy|date=12 February 2014|work=The Tennessean|access-date=14 February 2014}}</ref>

Swindell released his [[Cole Swindell (album)|self-titled debut album]] on February 18, 2014.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/4305396/cole-swindell-rides-chillin-it-to-label-deal |title=Cole Swindell Rides 'Chillin' It' to Label Deal |magazine=Billboard |date=2013-07-23 |access-date=2013-07-31}}</ref> Luke Bryan's guitarist, [[Michael Carter (musician)|Michael Carter]], produced the rest of the album. Along with [[Lee Brice]], Swindell opened Bryan's 2014 [[That's My Kind of Night Tour]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1715778/luke-bryan-announces-2014-tour.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018150352/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1715778/luke-bryan-announces-2014-tour.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=October 18, 2013 | title=Luke Bryan Announces 2014 Tour: Lee Brice, Cole Swindell Will Open Shows | publisher=CMT | date=2013-10-17}}</ref> "Chillin' It" became a top-five hit on [[Country Airplay]] and number 1 single on [[Hot Country Songs]]. The album's second single is "[[Hope You Get Lonely Tonight]]", which Swindell and Carter co-wrote with both members of [[Florida Georgia Line]], [[Brian Kelley]] and [[Tyler Hubbard]]. The album's third single, "[[Ain't Worth the Whiskey]]", was released to country radio on November 3, 2014. It reached number one on the Country Airplay chart in April 2015. The album's fourth single, "[[Let Me See Ya Girl]]", was released to country radio on April 20, 2015. It reached number two on the Country Airplay chart in November 2015.

On November 17, 2014, Swindell released a five-song digital EP, ''[[The Down Home Sessions]]''. The release coincided with his headlining tour of the same name.<ref name="down home">{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6327202/cole-swindell-down-home-sessions-ep |title=Cole Swindell Brings His Fans 'Down Home' With New EP |author= Chuck Dauphin |date= November 20, 2014 |magazine=Billboard }}</ref>

Swindell won the ACM New Artist of the Year Award in April 2015.<ref>[http://www.etonline.com/news/163084_cole_swindell_talks_acms_best_new_artist_of_the_year_win_i_never_want_to_let_it_go/ole Swindell Talks ACMs Best New Artist Award: 'I Never Want to Let It Go']{{Dead link|date=July 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ET Online. 19 April 2015.</ref>

===2015–2018: ''You Should Be Here''===
The album's first single, "[[You Should Be Here (Cole Swindell song)|You Should Be Here]]" was released to country radio on December 14, 2015. It was written with [[Ashley Gorley]]. It reached at number one on the Country Airplay and Hot Country Songs charts in April 2016. The album's second single, "[[Middle of a Memory]]" released to country radio on May 2, 2016. It reached at number one on the Country Airplay in November 2016. The album's third single, "[[Flatliner (song)|Flatliner]]" (featuring [[Dierks Bentley]]) released to country radio on January 23, 2017. It reached at number two on the Country Airplay in August 2017. The album's fourth single, "Stay Downtown" released to country radio on September 5, 2017. "You Should Be Here", "Middle of a Memory" and "Flatliner" all hit No.1 on [[Mediabase]] country radio singles chart.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://headlineplanet.com/home/2017/08/13/cole-swindells-flatliner-reaches-1-country-radio/|title=Cole Swindell's "Flatliner" Reaches #1 At Country Radio|date=2017-08-13|work=Headline Planet|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref>

Swindell also released a music video for the song which featured a video of him telling his father he received a record contract and subsequent montages of Cole and his brothers grieving outside of the family home and at their father's grave. The video also shows images of Swindell's rising popularity while clearly conveying that he wanted to be able to see his father and share this fame experience with him.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/12/14/cole-swindell-tells-dad-you-should-here-song/77067780/|title=Cole Swindell tells dad: 'You should be here' in song |author= Cindy Watts|date= December 14, 2015 |work=The Tennessean}}</ref>

===2018–present: ''All of It'' and ''Stereotype''===
Swindell released "[[Break Up in the End]]", the lead single from his third album, on February 23, 2018.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8286355/cole-swindell-break-up-in-the-end|title=It's Personal: Cole Swindell Finds the Heart Of 'Break Up In The End' |author=Tom Roland|date=April 4, 2018 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> Swindell's third album, ''[[All of It]]'', was released on August 17, 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://theboot.com/cole-swindell-2018-new-album-details-information/|title=Everything We Know About Cole Swindell's New Album, 'All of It'|author=Carena Liptak|date=June 1, 2018|work=The Boot}}</ref> After the album became available for pre-order in July 2018, Swindell released the number-one track "[[Love You Too Late]]" as a promotional single.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-love-you-too-late/|title=Cole Swindell Teases New Song, 'Love You Too Late'|last=Hermanson|first=Wendy|date=12 July 2018 |access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref> "Love You Too Late" was announced as the album's official second single, being released to radio on November 19, 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-love-you-too-late-music-video/ | title=Cole Swindell Brings the Action in 'Love You Too Late' Video | website=Taste of Country | date=July 31, 2019 | access-date=October 15, 2019 | author=Jacklyn Krol}}</ref>

The lead single from Swindell's fourth studio album, "[[Single Saturday Night]]", was released on May 22, 2020.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-single-saturday-night/|title=Cole Swindell Finds Love in 'Single Saturday Night' [LISTEN] |author=Cillea Houghton|date=May 22, 2020 |work=Taste of Country}}</ref> It was followed by "[[Never Say Never (Cole Swindell and Lainey Wilson song)|Never Say Never]]", a duet with [[Lainey Wilson]], on November 19, 2021.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-lainey-wilson-never-say-never/|title=Cole Swindell + Lainey Wilson's Smoldering 'Never Say Never' Recalls the Best Bad Decisions [Listen] |author=Billy Dukes|date=November 22, 2021 |work=Taste of Country}}</ref> Swindell released his fourth album ''[[Stereotype (Cole Swindell album)|Stereotype]]'' on April 8, 2022.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://themusicuniverse.com/cole-swindell-announces-sterotype/|title=Cole Swindell announces 'Stereotype' |author=Buddy Iahn|date=February 4, 2022 |work=The Music Universe}}</ref> Swindell followed the album up with its third single, "[[She Had Me at Heads Carolina]]", a remake of [[Jo Dee Messina]]'s 1996 single "[[Heads Carolina, Tails California]]". This single has gone on to become the biggest single of Swindell's career so far, having spent four weeks at number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart, as well as becoming his first Top 20 single on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and was certified [[Multi-Platinum|three-times]] Platinum by [[RIAA]].

==Personal life==
Swindell is married to Courtney Little, a former member of the [[Charlotte Honey Bees]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Singer Cole Swindell and Courtney Little Wed in Sonoma, 1 Year After Engagement |url=https://people.com/singer-cole-swindell-courtney-little-wed-in-sonoma-8663343 |website=Peoplemag |access-date=14 June 2024 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Who Is Cole Swindell's Fiancée? All About Courtney Little |url=https://people.com/who-is-courtney-little-cole-swindell-7964972 |website=Peoplemag |access-date=14 June 2024 |language=en}}</ref>
